oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Brown House: rear view
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 9521 Ooltewah-Georgetown Road, Ooltewah, Hamilton Co., TN

Color photograph of a brick house having a gable roof and chimney; large whole in brick wall below the roof peak; porch roof partially collapsed on the left side; two white screen doors visible with stone stairs; three rectangular windows between the two doors

The James Brown Farmstead in Hamilton County, Tennessee has long been recognized as a landmark of Cherokee history, settlement, and removal. Its significance derives from its associations with James Brown, an important Cherokee leader from 1806 to 1863, and the themes of westward expansion, Cherokee nationalism, Cherokee removal, and the Trail of Tears.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Dwellings; Historic buildings -- Tennessee
Houses
